page.title: 02Ecology - Woodland
page.content: Uncultivated and ungrazed land is quickly colonised here by saplings, except where bare rock is exposed. The most prolific colonisers on the limestone soils are ash and sycamore - for example - along Throughs Lane in Storth and on the steep banks of the old{Kendal Railway}cutting. Yews and hazels are common on the limestone hills. On the peaty soils across the estuary, the invading trees are chiefly birch and Scots pine. The only significant area of commercial woodland is{Foulshaw Moss,} west of the estuary. Thirty or forty years ago Scots pine were planted on the drier parts of the old peat moss and are now quite tall, though rather crowded and spindly. They should eventually produce useful timber.
